item.title: What's Up With the Child Tax Credit?
item.description: Taxpayers who claimed the child tax credit on their 2020 returns—or 2019 for those who haven’t yet filed for 2020—should be all set to receive monthly payments. The monthly max payment is $300 per child under 6 and $250 per child between ages 6 and 17. Until then, chat up a tax pro if:Your income increased significantly in 2021You’re concerned about a higher-than-usual tax bill next yearYou take turns with someone in claiming the child tax creditYour child turns 6 or 18 in 2021You’re too late to unenroll from the first payment, but you can discontinue the rest here. Parents who aren’t required to file taxes can sign up for payments on the non-filer portal. You’ll get the max payment when your AGI is below... You’ll get something when your AGI is below:$240,000 and you’re single$440,000 and you’re married filing jointly$240,000 and you’re a head of householdYou can calculate exactly how much you’ll get here. The IRS is looking back at your most recent return to calculate your monthly payment, but the actual tax credit amount is based on your 2021 situation. They’ll get the other half when they file their 2021 taxes next year.

item.title: Expanded Child Tax Credit Kicks in Today
item.description: In the biggest win for parents since the invention of the iPad, the IRS will send supersized checks for the expanded child tax credit (CTC) beginning today. Read more: Our personal finance writer Ryan Lasker put together a cheat sheet for the child tax credit that’ll help you figure out if you qualify, how much you’re eligible for, and whether you should opt out. Will it stick around?  Here’s why: The expanded child tax credit is expected to cut child poverty by nearly half, according to a study from Columbia University.

item.description: The backstory: In April, the MLB said it was moving the All-Star Game from Georgia to Denver due to Georgia’s new voting law. Either way, Denver businesses are happy to play host. item.title: Cuba Cracks Down on Protests in Wake of Worst Economic Crisis in Decades
item.description: President Obama abstained from a symbolic UN vote opposing the US’ embargo on Cuba for the first time in US history, signaling a move to repair relations. The crisis has pushed people to the brink—it’s very rare to see protests of this scale in Cuba, a country where the Communist regime keeps a close eye on dissidents.

item.title: Delta Causes Fresh Lockdowns and Higher Caseloads Across the World
item.description: Boosters are hereFacing rising cases, this week Israel will become the first country in the world to administer a Covid-19 booster vaccine shot; it’ll be given to adults with serious preexisting conditions. Experts warn that the number of deaths could soon rise in unvaccinated areas of the country, but for now they’re down 27% nationwide from two weeks ago. In the US, which is more or less fully reopened for business, cases rose 47% last week, the biggest increase since April 2020.

item.title: Musk Faces Legal Questions Over SolarCity Acquisition
item.description: As Reuters asks, “Does Elon Musk control Tesla Inc., or does Tesla control Elon Musk?” so how was this bad for Tesla shareholders exactly? Musk didn’t need much due diligence before buying SolarCity—after all, his cousins founded it in 2006 and Musk served as the chairman.  The detailsThe lawsuit alleges that Tesla’s acquisition of SolarCity reeked with conflicts of interest and that Musk failed to disclose liquidity problems at SolarCity.

item.title: Branson in Space: Risky or Reckless?
item.description: His personal ambitions are intertwined with the company’s—this space flight was inevitable.    Micron shares fell more than 6% following the news of Appleton’s death. A 2011 study found that CEOs with licenses to pilot small aircraft (an activity 30x more dangerous than driving a car) are 40% more likely to make a corporate acquisition and 15% more likely to take on greater leverage. The company has completed more than 20 test flights, but the mission has been delayed by technical issues and a pilot died in a test flight in 2014. Bottom line: When Richard Branson decided to create a space company, it’s probably because he wanted to go to space.
